The "Business Transparency on Trafficking and Slavery Act" requires disclosure of policies to eradicate slavery and forced labor in supply chains. The US is a major importer, and there is increasing demand for information on human rights impact. California passed a law in 2010 on this issue. The Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act of 1930 has exceptions for goods not produced in the US in sufficient quantities. Consumers do not have certain rights regarding goods made with forced labor. The Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act of 1930 has limited enforcement actions in the past 80 years due to the legislative intent to protect American manufacturers. Congress acknowledges forced labor, slavery, and human trafficking as severe abuses for commercial profit. The legislative framework to prevent abuse for commercial profit is inadequate, and legislation is needed to ensure businesses provide transparent information to consumers and investors to address forced labor, slavery, human trafficking, and child labor issues. SEC. 2. DISCLOSURE TO SEC RELATING TO SLAVERY CONDITIONS WITHIN PRODUCT SUPPLY CHAINS. Section 13 of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to require disclosures regarding forced labor, slavery, human trafficking, and child labor within supply chains. The Commission must promulgate regulations for reporting on measures taken to address these issues annually. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to require disclosures on forced labor, slavery, human trafficking, and child labor within supply chains. Companies must have policies to identify and eliminate these risks, prohibit the use of products for forced labor, and verify supply chains for these issues. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 amendment mandates disclosures on forced labor, slavery, human trafficking, and child labor in supply chains. Companies must assess risks, eliminate them, and conduct audits to ensure supplier compliance with company standards. Verification processes may involve third parties and consultations with unions or workers. The amendment to the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 requires companies to conduct audits of suppliers to evaluate compliance with standards on forced labor, slavery, human trafficking, and child labor in supply chains. It also involves assessing supply chain management systems, verifying supplier risk identification processes, and requiring suppliers to certify compliance with relevant laws. The amendment to the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 mandates companies to audit suppliers for compliance with standards on forced labor, slavery, human trafficking, and child labor in supply chains. Companies must maintain internal accountability standards, provide training on labor exploitation risks, and ensure recruitment practices align with company standards. The amendment to the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 requires companies to ensure suppliers adhere to company standards to eliminate exploitative labor practices, including forced labor, slavery, human trafficking, and child labor. Companies must conduct audits of labor recruiters and provide remediation to victims identified in the supply chain. The information in the annual report must be submitted electronically in an interactive data format and made publicly available on a searchable website by the Commission. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 amendment requires companies to publish information on their website regarding forced labor, slavery, human trafficking, and child labor. This disclosure must be easily accessible with a specific link on the homepage labeled "Policies to Address Forced Labor, Slavery, Human Trafficking and the Worst Forms of Child Labor." If a company does not have a website, they must provide the disclosure within 30 days upon request. The curr_chunk defines 'supply chain' as all suppliers of products, parts, and materials used by a company, and 'verification' as the process of evaluating compliance with labor standards.
